Title: Current status of DNA barcoding of aquatic hyphomycetes
Keywords:
Freshwaters, ITS, Litter decomposition, Molecular
identification
Abstract:
DNA barcoding is a rapid diagnostic approach in which
short DNA sequences (DNA barcodes) are used for species identification.
Aquatic hyphomycetes are a polyphyletic group of fungi that play a key
role in organic matter processing in freshwaters. The internal
transcribed spacer (ITS) region from rRNA gene was recently designated
as the most suitable barcode for fungal identification. In the current
study, we accessed all ITS sequences belonging to aquatic hyphomycete
species present in GenBank at the NCBI. We also generated new barcodes
based on ITS region for an additional 9 species, without published ITS
sequences. These new barcodes and all published ITS sequences were used
to construct a neighbor-joining tree to establish genetic relationships.
Results were congruent with those published in a recent study where
authors used a combination of ITS and LSU regions. To date, ca. 26% of
all described aquatic hyphomycete species have been connected with an
ITS barcode.
